td.h2: Anthropic launches Project Vend: Claude runs a real-world shop for a month

td.p: 33,294 Likes

Anthropic let Claude Sonnet 3.7 run a month-long vending store in its SF office. Claude handled inventory, pricing, and user messages using tools and Slack. Its fast supplier search showed promising technical capability.

How does it work at a high level?
Claude (nicknamed "Claudius") acted as the store owner and used web search, internal notes, simulated emails, and pricing tools to run the business. Human workers only executed physical tasks like restocking, following Claude’s instructions.

li.p: Used real-time web search to identify niche suppliers
Launched a “Custom Concierge” service for pre-ordering unusual items
Managed inventory and pricing logic with minimal prompts
Rejected unsafe or misuse-oriented prompts (e.g., jailbreaks)

td.p:
Main limitations
It lacked business-specific reasoning. Gave large discounts under social pressure. Errors like hallucinations or pricing errors weren’t easily corrected. Never made a profit; struggled with learning from mistakes
With domain fine-tuning and structured tools, AI agents like Claude could sustain autonomous business tasks but face critical alignment and reliability hurdles.

p.i: "One of the key reasons for Claude and other LLMs not being able to play the manger role successfully is their agreeability - it's what makes them great assistants but weak managers"

p.em: "It's the same sort of hallucination that conjures up twenty people in a "user panel" that tested a web app and gave their feedback on it when you ask LLM to analyse tool code. Nobody there, of course.

h2.strong: Spin up high-performance NVIDIA GPU clusters in minutes, not quarters

td.p: Waiting weeks to provision infrastructure delays experiments, slows teams, and burns budget.

p.strong: Lambda’s 1-Click Clusters give you pre-validated, GPU-ready infrastructure without cloud complexity.

li.p: Deploy high-performance clusters faster than standard cloud setups
Skip manual config with a simple, unified provisioning process
Isolate workloads at the hardware level for stronger security

p.strong: It’s purpose-built for GPU-heavy workloads, with

li.p: Flat pricing, no surprise egress or ingress fees
Unified provisioning across compute, storage, and networking

strong.a: Google launches Gemma 3n to run multimodal text, image, and audio on-device with just 2GB memory.

h2.a: How to Optimize your Prompt for Llama

td.p: 1,498 Likes

Learn how to migrate and optimize GPT-style prompts for Llama. Set up projects, analyze YAML configs, and run reproducible migrations to achieve consistent, measurable prompt performance gains without manual tweaks.
1,221 Likes

Refine older prompts for GPT‑4.1 using this notebook. Identify vague instructions, critique phrasing, auto-generate clearer versions, and iteratively align prompts with GPT‑4.1’s stricter interpretation patterns.

h2.a: Hitchhiker’s Guide to RAG with ChatGPT API and LangChain

td.p: 1,028 Likes

Build a simple Python RAG pipeline with ChatGPT API and LangChain. Process local text files, and ground model outputs in domain-specific context to reduce hallucinations. Use reproducible, scriptable components end-to-end.

td.h2: Automate Web Data Collection with AutoScraper in Python

td.p: Use autoscraper to automate web data collection without manual selectors. Unlike BeautifulSoup or XPath, autoscraper learns patterns by example.
Provide a sample target string, and it generalizes rules to fetch similar elements. This approach cuts down boilerplate and fits machine learning workflows where fresh web signals improve models.
Apply it to gather research papers, public benchmarks, or news updates programmatically. Always verify you follow site terms.

pre.code:
from autoscraper import AutoScraper
url = 'https://www.bbc.com/news'
wanted_list = ['BBC headline text here']
scraper = AutoScraper()
result = scraper.build(url, wanted_list)
print(result)

td.p: Use the trained scraper on new pages to scale data extraction efficiently.
